A BERNSTEIN TYPE THEOREM FOR SELF-SIMILAR
SHRINKERS
LU WANG
Abstract. In this note, we prove that smooth self-shrinkers in Rn+1 , that
are entire graphs, are hyperplanes. Previously Ecker and Huisken showed that
smooth self-shrinkers, that are entire graphs and have at most polynomial
growth, are hyperplanes. The point of this note is that no growth assumption
at infinity is needed.

1. Introduction
In this note, we show that smooth self-shrinkers in Rn+1 , that are entire graphs,
are hyperplanes. A smooth one-parameter family of hypersurfaces, F : (0, T ) ×

where n is the unit normal of Mt = F (t, M ) and H = div(n). Self-shrinkers represent a special class of solutions of equation (1.1), which do not change shape under
mean curvature flow. Namely, for self-shrinkers, a later time slice is a scaled down
copy of an earlier slice. Self-shrinkers play a crucial role in studying the singularities of mean curvature flow. For instance, in [11] and [12], Huisken discovered a
monotonicity formula for mean curvature flow and proved that, around the singular
point
√ (x0 , t0 ), if the blow-up rate of curvature is bounded above by a multiple of
1/ t0 − t, then the rescaled hypersurfaces moving by mean curvature converge to
a self-shrinker smoothly. In the recent work of Colding and Minicozzi, they showed
that the only smooth embedded entropy stable self-shrinkers with polynomial volume growth in Rn+1 are hyperplanes, n-spheres and cylinders Rk ×S n−k , 0 < k < n,
and classified the generic singularities of mean curvature flow; see [2]. On the other
hand, self-shrinkers are minimal hypersurfaces in Rn+1 under the conformal metric

x |2 /2n)δij ; see [1], [2] and [3]. In minimal hypersurface theory, the
Bernstein Theorem is one of the most fundamental theorems, and has many important applications, such as uniqueness and regularity of minimal hypersurfaces.
Thus it is natural to ask whether there is a Bernstein type theorem for self-shrinkers.
Ecker and Huisken studied mean evolution of entire graphs in a series of papers beginning with [7] in 1989. In particular, they proved in the appendix of [7] that
smooth self-shrinkers in Rn+1 , that are entire graphs and have at most polynomial
growth, are hyperplanes. Later, in [8], they derived various interior estimates for
mean curvature flow and proved the existence of smooth mean envolution of graphs
with only locally Lipschitz initial data. Also, in [5], Colding and Minicozzi proved
sharp gradient and area estimates for graphs moving by mean curvature. In this
note, we study self-shrinkers using the L-stability operator, which was introduced
by Colding and Minicozzi in [2] and [3]. We give an elementary proof of a Berntein
